learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the central themes and concepts in Western thought on empire.
Appreciate the intellectual challenge of recovering what past authors meant by the things they wrote.
Recognise and understand the importance of conflict and struggle in the development of ideas.
Be aware of the historical reception and re-interpretation of imperial and colonial ideas.
Be able to position key ideas and texts in relation to diverse contexts and interests.
Understand the challenges and opportunities in studying contemporary colonial legacies.
Demonstrate an ability to communicate understanding of empire through modes of written and oral expression appropriate to the humanities disciplines.

assessments.task_description:
Length: 2,000 words

*A list of essay questions will be circulated during the semester.

The essay should focus on the primary text, rather than secondary sources, but secondary sources should be consulted.

Students are encouraged to use secondary sources in preparing their essay, but these MUST be selected from the WCIV2100 Further Readings list (found on Blackboard). If a student wishes to use secondary sources outside this list, permission must be sought from the course coordinator in advance (at least 48 hours before the due date) with justification for each source. Penalties will be applied for using secondary sources not on the WCIV2100 Further Readings list.

**Note on AI use: While UQ in its wisdom prevents me from prohibiting AI use in assessments, I strongly encourage you to approach AI tools thoughtfully and limit their role in the preparation and writing of your essay. On submission of your video presentation, your essay, and any other written submissions for WCIV2100 you are required to fill out the course AI Declaration Coversheet.

** Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics will be available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Task Description: This is a 10-minute individual oral examination designed to assess your understanding of course texts through spontaneous discussion.

You will be scheduled for an individual meeting with the course coordinator.

  1. Text selection and reading: At the start of your oral assessment, you will nominate two texts (and passages from each text) from the course readings (excluding any text that is the focus of your research essay). The coordinator will select one of your nominated texts and ask you to read aloud a selected passage. Bring physical copies of both selected passages to your assessment (including page numbers in the prescribed course text). Students should not bring any other printed matter to the oral assessment (eg., a prepared print-out of the opening statement or other extended notes).
  2. Opening statement: The coordinator will then ask you to provide a brief exegesis and explanation of the chosen passage.
  3. Follow-up discussion: Follow-up questions will be asked to help you expand, clarify, or deepen your initial response. The coordinator will also pose further questions, asking you to relate your selected passage and text to other texts studied in the course and to broader course-related themes and concepts.

All questions are designed to give you opportunities to demonstrate your knowledge—they are not intended to trick or intimidate you.

The oral assessment will be recorded for assessment purposes (audio only). 

Preparation:

  • Review all course texts thoroughly, focusing on key arguments, themes, and concepts.
  • Select two texts as the starting point of your oral assessment (excluding the subject of your essay).
  • Choose a specific passage from each text that you consider significant for understanding politics or a specific political concept or argument.
  • Practice articulating your thoughts about texts clearly and concisely.
  • Bring physical copies of both selected passages to your assessment
  • Be prepared to discuss any text, including the one you wrote about in your research essay


Assessment Criteria:

Content (Knowledge & Analysis):

  • Completeness and accuracy of responses
  • Demonstration of close engagement with the text
  • Quality of analysis and interpretation
  • Understanding of connections between the text and course themes
  • Breadth and depth of knowledge displayed

 

Communication (Eloquence & Clarity):

  • Clear oral expression and organization of ideas
  • Effective use of relevant concepts, terminology, and examples
  • Ability to construct and articulate persuasive arguments
  • Overall coherence and engagement in scholarly discussion


Note: This assessment evaluates your ability to think and communicate spontaneously about course materials, demonstrating both your understanding of the texts and your capacity to engage in scholarly discussion about course-related themes and concepts.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Liberalism & Empire (Mill)

This lecture focuses on two essays by the great political theorist of Victorian Britain, John Stuart Mill: 'A Few Words on Non-Intervention' (1859) and 'Civilisation' (1836). The lecture will reflect on how a political theorist best known for his robust defence of liberty could also defend imperial governance.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

This lecture focuses on Michel de Montaigne's essay 'On Cannibals' (1580-92), an early modern attempt to hold an ethnographic mirror up to Europe during a period of violent confessional conflict.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

Week 5: Early Modern Europe & the Other (Behn)

This lecture focuses on Aphra Behn's short work of prose fiction, Oroonoko, or the Royal Slave: A True History (1688). The lecture contextualises the novella in the tumultuous political context of 17th-century Britain and the Atlantic slave trade.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

Week 6: Early Modern Europe & the Other (Defoe)

This lecture focuses on Daniel Defoe's famous adventure story of the castaway, Robinson Crusoe (1719). The lecture contextualises the novel in Britain's Protestant political culture, its maritime exploration and colonialism, and the violence of piracy and slavery on the high seas.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

Week 7: Anticolonial Resistance (Fanon)

This lecture focuses on Frantz Fanon's searing critique of colonialism in The Wretched of the Earth (1961), a book considered by many to be a foundational postcolonial text. The lecture contextualises the book in the Cold War politics of decolonisation and the philosophy of existentialism.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

Week 10: Frontier Imaginaries (Coppola)

This lecture focuses on Francis Ford Coppola's film about America's experience in the Vietnam War, Apocalypse Now (1979), a film loosely based on Conrad's Heart of Darkness. The lecture contextualises the film in the Cold War, decolonisation, and America's imperial intervention and warfare in Southeast Asia.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

Week 11: Frontier Imaginaries (Scott)

This lecture focuses on Indigenous author, Kim Scott's historical novel, That Deadman Dance (2010). The story of contact on the 'friendly frontier' at King George Sound in the early 19th century raises questions about settler-colonialism's devastating impact on the people, language, history, and culture of the Noongar people.
